A local transit company sells a monthly pass for $117 that allows an unlimited number og trips of any length. 
Tickets for invidual trips cost $(1.81, 2.82, 3.4) depending on the lenght of the trip.
What is the minimum number of trips per month for which  a monthly pass could cost les than  purchasing invidual tickets for trip?
explanation:
The correct answer is 35. 
The minimum number of individual trips for which the cost of the monthly pass is less than the cost of individual tickets can be found by assuming the maximum cost
of the individual tickets, $3.4. If n tickets costing $3.4 each are purchased in one month the inequality 117 < 3.4n represents this situation. 
Dividing both sides of the inequality by 3.4yields 34.411764705882355 < n, which is equivalent to n > 34.411764705882355. Since only a whole number of tickets can be purchased, 
it follows that 35 is the minimum number of trips
